• The Benban Solar Park, located near Aswan, has a total capacity of 1650 MW and generates approximately 3.8 TWh annually, making it the fourth-largest solar power plant in the world.
• The Gabal El Zeit wind farm, costing €340 million, covers an area of 100 square kilometers, comprises 300 turbines, and has a generation capacity of 580 MW.

• Egypt and Cyprus are exploring the EuroAfrica Interconnector project, which involves laying a 2 GW HVDC undersea power cable connecting Egypt, Cyprus, and Greece to integrate Egypt into the European power grid.
• The EuroAfrica Interconnector aims to position Egypt as an electricity hub between Europe and Africa, enhancing regional energy security.
• On 21 November 2017, the president of Egypt and the prime minister of Cyprus met in Nicosia to express full support for the EuroAfrica Interconnector, emphasizing its strategic importance.
• On 29 October 2007, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak authorized the construction of several nuclear power plants; however, these plans did not progress during his leadership.
• On 19 November 2015, Egypt and Russia signed an initial agreement for Russia to build and finance Egypt’s first nuclear power plant.

• In December 2017, preliminary contracts were signed for the construction of four VVER-1200 nuclear reactor units, with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi and Russian President Vladimir Putin present.
• The permit for the first nuclear unit was issued by the Egyptian Nuclear and Radiological Regulatory Authority (ENRRA) in June 2022.
• Construction of the first nuclear unit began with the pouring of safety-related concrete in July 2022.
• In October 2022, ENRRA approved the construction of the second nuclear unit, which officially commenced on 19 November 2022.
• Egypt's oil consumption is surpassing its oil production, indicating increasing domestic demand outpacing local supply.
• The Egyptian government has historically prioritized expanding the petrochemical industry and increasing natural gas exports as key components of its energy strategy.
• By the year 2009, approximately 38% of Egypt’s locally produced natural gas was allocated for export purposes.
• Crude oil production in Egypt peaked at 941,000 barrels per day (bbl/d) in 1993 but declined to 630,000 bbl/d by 2008, reflecting a significant decrease over this period.
• Due to declining crude oil output, Egypt shifted its focus toward natural gas development and exports.
• In 2008, Egypt’s natural gas production reached 48.3 billion cubic meters (bcm), but rising domestic consumption caused the country to become a net oil importer by 2008–2009.
• In 2014, Egypt shifted policy to prioritize domestic gas consumption over exports, leading to a substantial reduction in international gas supply commitments.
• Egypt signed a 15-year gas import agreement with Israel to purchase 7 billion cubic meters (bcm) annually from the Leviathan field.
• In 2015, BP announced a $12 billion investment in Egypt’s natural gas sector, focusing mainly on the West Nile Delta project, which produces nearly 1 billion cubic feet per day (bcf/d).

• BP also developed the Atoll field, with a production capacity of 300 million standard cubic feet per day (MMscf/d), and engaged in the North Damietta concession, with production from the Qattameya discovery starting in 2020.
• The Zohr gas field, discovered by Eni in 2015, is the largest natural gas find in the Mediterranean, with estimated reserves of 30 trillion cubic feet (Tcf).
• Production at Zohr began in December 2017, reaching 2.7 billion cubic feet per day (bcf/d) by August 2019.
• Technical challenges have recently reduced Zohr’s output, resulting in domestic supply constraints and increased dependence on imported gas.
• Egypt has secured agreements with Cyprus to import gas from the Cronos and Aphrodite fields, which is processed in Idku and Damietta for liquefied natural gas (LNG) exports to Europe.
• Efforts are underway to revitalize Zohr’s production through new drilling plans aimed at increasing output by 220 million cubic feet per day (MMcf/d).
• Egypt’s construction industry was valued at USD 55.04 billion in 2025 and is projected to reach USD 82.34 billion by 2030, reflecting an annual growth rate of 8.4%.
• The sector contributes approximately 14% to Egypt’s Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• Growth in the construction sector is driven by state-led infrastructure investments and increasing foreign interest, notably from Gulf sovereign funds.
• Real estate remains a key driver of the construction industry, with USD 20 billion invested in Cairo in 2022, primarily in housing developments.
• The market has been further diversified through the introduction of real estate trading on the Egyptian Exchange and the launch of a dedicated real estate fund.
• Major infrastructure projects include the construction of the central business district in Egypt’s new administrative capital in 2022.

• Significant infrastructure projects encompass Cairo Metro Lines 3 and 4, the two-line Cairo Monorail, and the high-speed rail network, all of which are transforming Egypt’s transportation infrastructure.
• Large-scale energy projects complement infrastructure development, notably the El Dabaa Nuclear Power Plant and various renewable energy initiatives.

• Flagship developments include the proposed new administrative capital of Egypt, launched in 2015, and New Alamein, a north coast city covering 48,000 feddans, both part of Egypt’s fourth-generation cities initiative.
• Residential construction is the leading market segment, accounting for 37% of the sector in 2024, supported by a young population demographic and government pro-housing policies.
• Industrial construction is the fastest-growing segment, with an expected annual growth rate of 12% through 2029, driven by foreign investment and the development of specialized industrial zones.
• Key construction firms operating in Egypt include Hassan Allam Construction, Dorra Holding, Arab Contractors, Orascom Construction, and SIAC Industrial Construction & Engineering.
• The Central Bank of Egypt functions as the national reserve bank, responsible for regulating the financial market and overseeing the Egyptian pound.
• Since the 1990s, Egypt’s banking sector has undergone significant reforms, leading to a liberalized and modernized system that aligns with international standards.

• By late 2024, total bank assets in Egypt reached approximately 21 trillion Egyptian pounds (USD 420 billion), representing a substantial increase from 633 billion Egyptian pounds (USD 101 billion) in 2004.
• The banking system in Egypt dates back to 1856, illustrating a long-standing financial history that has evolved through processes such as privatization, mergers, and foreign bank exits.
• Notable foreign bank exit includes Société Générale’s 2012 sale of its National Société Générale Bank to QNB Al Ahli.
• Despite the growth of the private sector, state-owned commercial banks continue to dominate Egypt’s banking landscape.
• Financial inclusion has expanded significantly, with 74.8% of Egyptians aged 15 and above using financial accounts, totaling approximately 52 million users by 2024.
• Financial account usage spans multiple channels, including banks, Egypt Post, mobile wallets such as Vodafone Cash and MobiCash, and prepaid cards like Meeza.
• Women’s financial inclusion has increased by 295% since 2016, driven by policies and initiatives aimed at empowering women financially, reaching a participation rate of 68.8%.
• Youth participation in financial services has grown by 65% from 2020 to 2024, reaching 53.1%.
• The fintech sector in Egypt has expanded 5.5 times since 2020, with 177 startups operating within the industry.
• Egypt ranks 10th among emerging markets for fintech development.
• Growth in fintech is primarily driven by digital payments, lending platforms, and B2B marketplaces, supported by policies promoting financial inclusion.
• Over 60% of Egypt’s population is under 30 years old, contributing to high youth adoption rates of digital financial services.
• Challenges facing the sector include cybersecurity risks, regulatory gaps, and disparities in digital literacy.
• The origins of Egypt's stock exchange date back to 1883 with the establishment of the first futures market in Alexandria.
• In 1902, the Brokers' Syndicate was formed, introducing the first set of regulations governing stock market activities in Egypt.
• The Egyptian Exchange (EGX) today comprises the Cairo and Alexandria stock exchanges, operating under a unified trading, clearing, and settlement system.
• The EGX serves as the primary platform for trading equities, bonds, and various financial instruments within Egypt.

• The exchange has undergone multiple phases of reform, including privatization initiatives, regulatory adjustments, and structural enhancements aimed at improving market liquidity and attracting foreign investment.
• Egypt’s stock market has experienced fluctuations influenced by global economic conditions, foreign capital flows, and domestic policy changes.
• Periods of initial public offering (IPO) activity and privatization efforts have contributed significantly to market expansion.
• External shocks such as global financial downturns and geopolitical events have periodically impacted the performance of the Egyptian stock market.
• Government-led reforms have included revisions to listing rules, the introduction of sectoral indices, and measures to increase market depth.
• Specific reforms to enhance market depth include the establishment of a treasury bonds index and the approval for the operation of special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs).
• Future plans for market development involve launching EGYCOMEX, the Egyptian Commodities Exchange, and introducing derivatives trading.
• These initiatives aim to diversify financial instruments and strengthen Egypt’s position as a regional financial hub.
• The headquarters of Telecom Egypt is a key institution within Egypt’s telecommunications sector, serving as a central hub for the country's major telecom operations.
• Egypt’s telecommunications sector began liberalization in 1998, initiating a gradual process to increase private sector participation in mobile telephony and internet services.

• In 2004, the Information Technology Industry Development Agency (ITIDA) was established under Law 15, with objectives to drive Egypt’s digital transformation, implement e-signature legislation, and promote an export-oriented IT sector.

• Deregulation of Egypt’s ICT market occurred in 2006, following Egypt’s accession to the World Trade Organization's (WTO) Information Technology Agreement in 2003, which opened the market to increased competition and foreign investment.

• By 2007, Egypt had approximately 10 million fixed telephone lines, 31 million mobile subscribers, and 8.1 million internet users, indicating significant growth in telecommunications infrastructure and user base.

• The ICT sector has become a major contributor to Egypt’s economy, expanding by 15.2% in fiscal year 2022/2023 and accounting for 5.1% of the country’s Gross Domestic Product (GDP), up from 4.4% in 2019/2020.
• Investments in the ICT sector reached $4.2 billion during 2022/2023, representing a 20% increase compared to the previous year, reflecting sector growth and investor confidence.
• The telecommunications market in Egypt operates under a unified license system, with key industry players including Telecom Egypt, Vodafone, Orange, Etisalat Egypt, and Ericsson.
• Egypt’s ICT market is projected to grow from $23.6 billion in 2025 to $53.1 billion by 2030, at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 17.61%, indicating robust future expansion.
• The government’s Digital Egypt initiative aims to transform Egypt into a digitally-driven society by expanding digital infrastructure, fostering innovation, and modernizing public services.

• As part of the broader Egypt Vision 2030, the government has integrated 33,000 institutions into a secured digital network and enhanced online services, thereby improving transparency and operational efficiency.
• Between 2019 and 2022, mobile internet subscriptions increased by 77.9%, from 39 million to 69.4 million, demonstrating rapid growth in mobile internet adoption.
• Total mobile subscriptions in Egypt reached 106.2 million by December 2023, reflecting widespread mobile connectivity.
• Internet penetration in Egypt reached 72.2% in early 2024, with approximately 82 million internet users across the country.
• Egypt leads Africa in internet speed rankings, highlighting its advanced telecommunications infrastructure relative to the continent.
• The country is projected to generate $3.5 billion in smartphone revenue by 2025, with an expected annual growth rate of 6.11% until 2029, indicating a strong and expanding smartphone market.

• Transport in Egypt is primarily centered around Cairo and follows settlement patterns along the Nile River, which spans approximately 1,600 km (990 miles), along with major canals of equal length serving local transportation needs.

• Since 2014, the National Roads Project has implemented significant upgrades to Egypt’s road infrastructure, adding 6,300 km of new roads and upgrading 8,400 km at a total cost of 265 billion Egyptian pounds.
• These improvements expanded Egypt’s main roads by 29.8%, reaching a total length of 30,500 km, and elevated Egypt’s ranking in the Road Quality Index from 118th globally in 2015 to 18th in 2024.
• Egypt’s railway network extends approximately 4,800 km (3,000 miles) and is operated by Egyptian National Railways.

• In 2021, the National Authority for Tunnels signed a $4.5 billion contract with Siemens Mobility, Orascom Construction, and Arab Contractors to develop a 660 km (410 miles) electrified high-speed rail line connecting Ain Sokhna, Mersa Matruh, and Alexandria.

• This high-speed rail line is referred to as the "Green Line" or "Suez Canal on rails" and is designed to carry both freight and passengers, utilizing Velaro high-speed trains, Desiro regional sets, and Vectron freight locomotives.
• Two additional high-speed rail lines were announced in 2022, planned to connect Greater Cairo to Aswan and Luxor to Hurghada and Safaga.
• Egypt Air, along with private carriers such as Nile Air and Air Cairo, operate frequent domestic flights from Cairo International Airport to major tourist destinations across Egypt.
• The Suez Canal, managed by the Suez Canal Authority, is a critical global shipping route linking the Mediterranean Sea and the Red Sea, facilitating international maritime trade.
• Egypt’s main ports include Alexandria, Port Said, and Damietta on the Mediterranean coast, and Suez, Ain Sokhna, and Safaga on the Red Sea coast.
• Tourism in Egypt experienced significant growth after 1975, following government measures to ease visa restrictions and invest in tourism infrastructure.
• By 1981, tourist arrivals in Egypt increased to 1.8 million, demonstrating early growth in the sector.
• Tourist arrivals continued to rise, reaching 14.7 million in 2010, reflecting sustained expansion over the decades.
• The COVID-19 pandemic caused a sharp decline in Egypt’s tourism sector, with revenues dropping to $4 billion in 2020 and tourist arrivals decreasing to 3.5 million.
• In February 2022, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) identified Egypt’s tourism sector as the biggest loser from the pandemic’s economic impact.

• The Egyptian government launched several projects to bolster tourism, notably including the development of the Grand Egyptian Museum, which aims to be the largest museum in the world upon completion.
• The Grand Egyptian Museum is designed to showcase Egypt’s extensive archaeological heritage and strengthen its position as a leading global tourist destination.
• In 2024, Egypt set a new record by attracting 15.7 million tourists, surpassing the previous year's 14.9 million, indicating a robust recovery from pandemic-related declines.
• The increase in tourist numbers in 2024 is attributed to government efforts to improve security and support the tourism sector.
• Tourism revenues in 2024 reached $14.1 billion, marking a significant recovery from the lows of 2020.
• Egypt’s long-term tourism strategy aims to attract 30 million tourists annually by 2028 through continued infrastructure development and enhancement of the tourist experience.
• In 2024, Egypt’s top source markets for tourists included Germany, Russia, and Saudi Arabia.
• Egypt’s defence industry is among the oldest and most extensive in the Arab world, comprising a network of state-owned enterprises and a growing private sector.
• The industry produces small arms, munitions, drones, armored vehicles, and naval vessels, often through local manufacturing or co-production agreements.
• In 2020, Egypt launched a $479 million weapons manufacturing strategy aimed at modernizing 84 production lines to enhance self-sufficiency and export capabilities.
• The country leverages partnerships and events such as the Egypt Defence Expo (EDEX) to showcase its defence capabilities and position itself as a regional defence hub.
• The Ministry of Military Production oversees several firms, including Abu Zaabal Specialized Industries, Abu Zaabal Engineering Industries, and the Armoured Production and Repair Factory.
• The Armoured Production and Repair Factory produces systems such as the M1A1 Abrams tank, K9A1EGY artillery, RAAD 200 multiple rocket launcher, and Sinai 200 missile system.
• The Ministry also oversees Thales & Benha Electronics S.A.E., a joint venture with Thales Group, focused on co-producing communications and electronic systems.
• The Arab Organization for Industrialization (AOI) manages companies like Kader, Sakr, and Arab American Vehicles, as well as joint ventures such as Arab British Dynamics.
• AOI operates aerospace and engine factories in Helwan, producing aircraft such as the Alpha Jet and K-8E, and is pursuing licensed production of the KAI T-50 Golden Eagle trainer aircraft.

• The Alexandria Shipyard constructs naval vessels including corvettes, frigates, and patrol vessels, and has partnered with Naval Group and ThyssenKrupp Marine Systems to produce the Gowind 2500 and Meko A200 class ships locally.
• Private sector companies include Robotics Engineering Systems, which specializes in drones, smart munitions, and guided missiles.
• Amstone is another private firm developing advanced unmanned aerial systems (UAS) and naval systems.

• In 2024, Egypt launched a national policy to localize semiconductor and electronic chip manufacturing, designating the sector as a strategic priority for economic growth and technological self-reliance.
• The policy offers incentives such as tax breaks, land access, and technical support to encourage investment in semiconductors, embedded systems, and circuit design.

• This initiative is part of the broader _Egypt Makes Electronics_ program, a presidential strategy initiated in 2015 aimed at advancing high-value electronics design and manufacturing while generating employment in labor-intensive production sectors.

• To oversee implementation, the Egyptian government established the National Council for the Localization of Semiconductor Technology, chaired by the Prime Minister and including representatives from key ministries.

• The council's responsibilities include setting strategic direction, monitoring investments, addressing regulatory barriers, and coordinating efforts with both domestic and international stakeholders.
• A key component of the policy involves integrating local mineral resources into microelectronics supply chains to bolster domestic resource utilization.

• The policy also encompasses training initiatives, incentives for investors, and a national roadmap designed to facilitate integration into global value chains, with support from an international consultant.

• In 2024, Egypt partnered with China's Tsinghua Unigroup to establish a $300 million investment fund focused on semiconductors and artificial intelligence, with over 80% of the capital contributed by Chinese investors in collaboration with Egyptian partners.

• As of 2025, Egypt hosts 23 semiconductor startups, including notable companies such as Si-Ware Systems (specializing in ASICs and MEMS), Avelabs (focused on embedded software for the automotive industry), SilMinds (developing hardware acceleration solutions for high-performance computing), Wasiela (designing communication IP cores and digital media systems), and NeoSpectra (known for MEMS-based spectral sensors).
• InfiniLink, an Egyptian semiconductor startup founded in 2023, secured $10 million in seed funding in 2025, representing one of the largest deep-tech seed rounds in the MENA region.
• InfiniLink specializes in next-generation, energy-efficient optical transceiver chiplets intended for telecom, AI data centers, and IoT infrastructure.
• In 2024, only one Egyptian company was listed in the Forbes Global 2000 list, which ranks the top 2000 public companies worldwide annually by Forbes magazine.
• The Egyptian company featured in the Forbes Global 2000 was Commercial International Bank (CIB).
• Commercial International Bank was ranked 1663rd globally on the list.
• CIB's reported financial figures for 2024 include a revenue of $4.67 billion, profits of $0.967 billion, assets totaling $20.61 billion, and a market value of $4.83 billion.

• Forbes Middle East published a separate ranking in 2024 of the top 50 listed companies in Egypt, highlighting key publicly traded firms not included in the global list but significant to Egypt’s economy.
• Following Commercial International Bank in the Egyptian national ranking were QNB Al Ahli and Elsewedy Electric, each with a market capitalization of $1.4 billion.
• The next companies in the top ten Egyptian firms were Telecom Egypt (4th), Orascom Construction (5th), and Talaat Mostafa Group (6th).
• The remaining top ten included Egypt Kuwait Holding, Faisal Islamic Bank of Egypt, Abu Qir Fertilizers, and Misr Fertilizers Production Company.
• The banking and financial services sector dominated the Egyptian top companies, with 16 entries contributing a total of $8.4 billion in sales and holding $58.5 billion in assets.
• The real estate and construction sector was represented by nine firms among Egypt’s top companies.
• The industrial sector accounted for seven of Egypt’s leading companies.
• Historically, private equity has played a limited role in business financing in Egypt.
• The Egyptian government has initiated several reforms to improve the investment climate and attract foreign direct investment (FDI).
• The Investment Law of 2017 was introduced to streamline procedures and provide investor incentives.
• Following the 2017 Investment Law, Egypt enacted a new company law and bankruptcy law in 2018 to enhance the legal framework for business operations.
• A customs law was implemented in 2020 to facilitate trade and customs procedures.
• These legal amendments aimed to create a more efficient business environment and improve Egypt’s attractiveness to investors.
• Efforts to simplify company registration processes and encourage foreign participation contributed to Egypt becoming one of Africa’s leading FDI destinations between 2016 and 2020.

• To further boost economic attractiveness, Egypt implemented fiscal reforms including reductions in corporate tax rates and cuts in trade tariffs, targeting increased foreign investment and economic growth.

• The government pursued large-scale infrastructure projects such as transportation modernization, development of new urban communities, and the expansion of the Suez Canal to reduce logistical costs, improve trade efficiency, and provide better facilities for investors.

• As part of reform initiatives, Egypt introduced "golden licenses," a single-approval mechanism allowing investors to acquire land and commence operations without multiple approvals from various government bodies.
• The General Authority for Investment and Free Zones (GAFI) oversees the golden license program, which aims to reduce bureaucracy and attract FDI.
• As of March 2024, 26 golden licenses had been granted under this program.
• In July 2023, President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi ratified Law No. 159 of 2023, eliminating exemptions for state-owned enterprises to ensure equal regulatory treatment for all investors.
• The government introduced a citizenship-by-investment program, offering residency and citizenship in exchange for financial contributions to encourage foreign capital inflows.
• Despite these reforms, challenges such as corruption and the need for improved enforcement of regulatory frameworks continue to impact investor confidence.
• In 2024, Egypt scored 30 out of 100 on Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index, ranking 130th out of 180 countries.
• The data presented pertains to the year 2021 and is expressed in nominal monetary values.

• The total GDP of Egypt in 2021, converted to US dollars, was approximately 422.142 billion USD.
• Cairo, the capital city, had the highest regional GDP, amounting to 1,876.650 billion EGP, equivalent to 119.543 billion USD.
• Giza ranked second in regional GDP with 770.071 billion EGP (49.054 billion USD).
• Alexandria's GDP was 565.876 billion EGP, or 36.046 billion USD, making it the third-largest contributor.
• Qalyubiyya contributed 339.316 billion EGP (21.614 billion USD).
• Sharqia's regional GDP was 302.065 billion EGP (19.242 billion USD).
• Dakahlia had a GDP of 294.016 billion EGP, approximately 18.729 billion USD.
• Beheira's GDP stood at 288.857 billion EGP (18.400 billion USD).
• Port Said contributed 190.154 billion EGP, or 12.113 billion USD.
• Gharbia's GDP was 173.763 billion EGP (11.069 billion USD).
• Monufia's regional GDP was 157.267 billion EGP (10.018 billion USD).
• Kafr El Sheikh contributed 151.053 billion EGP (9.622 billion USD).
• Faiyum's GDP was 133.504 billion EGP, equivalent to 8.504 billion USD.
• Minya's regional GDP was 130.976 billion EGP (8.343 billion USD).
• Asyut contributed 126.143 billion EGP (8.035 billion USD).
• Suez's GDP was 119.129 billion EGP, or 7.589 billion USD.
• Matrouh's regional GDP stood at 115.552 billion EGP (7.361 billion USD).

• South Sinai's GDP was 58.386 billion EGP (3.719 billion USD).
• North Sinai contributed 48.932 billion EGP (3.117 billion USD).

• Egypt has faced ongoing challenges in implementing effective policies to combat poverty, with past efforts often disproportionately benefiting wealthier segments of society.
• Historically, subsidies on food, electricity, and petroleum have primarily aided non-poor populations, failing to adequately address the needs of the impoverished.
• The fertility rate in Egypt decreased from 6.6 children per woman in the 1960s to 3.2 children per woman in 2021, although it remains high relative to global standards.
• Egypt’s population increased from 44 million in 1981 to over 106 million in recent years, with the country facing significant overpopulation challenges that hinder poverty alleviation efforts.
• Overpopulation continues to be one of the most significant obstacles in confronting poverty within Egypt.
• The country’s dependence on international loans, including those from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), has sometimes exacerbated hardships for the population, rather than alleviating them.
• In August 2022, Egypt sought another international loan amid rising prices, which drew criticism of economic policies perceived to primarily benefit elites rather than the broader population.
• The poverty rate in Egypt increased from 19 percent in 2005 to 21 percent in 2009, as reported by then Minister of Economic Development, Othman Mohamed Othman.
• In 2010, the national poverty rate was recorded at 24.3%, rising to approximately 30% by 2015.
• A 2019 World Bank report indicated that 60% of Egypt’s population was either poor or vulnerable to poverty.
• As of 2020, Egypt’s population was approximately 102 million, with 33% of the population under the age of 14.
• Around 30% of the Egyptian population was living below the poverty line in 2020.
• By 2021, the percentage of the population living below the poverty line slightly declined to 29.7%.
• The Egyptian armed forces exert substantial influence over Egypt's economy, with military-run companies playing a pivotal role across various industries.

• These military enterprises contribute significantly to public spending on housing and infrastructure, including sectors such as cement and food production, as well as infrastructure development like roads and bridges.
• According to a study by the Carnegie Middle East Centre, the Egyptian army controls approximately 25% of public spending allocated to housing and infrastructure.

• Despite Egypt’s commitments to reduce the military’s economic footprint as part of an agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF), recent developments suggest an opposing trend of expanding military economic activities.

• The National Service Products Organization (NSPO), a firm under military ownership, is currently constructing new factories for the production of fertilizers, irrigation machines, and veterinary vaccines.

• The Egyptian government has been discussing for two years the sale of stakes in military-run companies Safi and Wataniya; however, despite claims of receiving offers, there are observable asset transfers, such as the rebranding of Wataniya franchises into ChillOut stations.

• The expanding economic influence of the military—from petrol stations to media outlets—has suppressed competition, hindered private investment, and contributed to slower economic growth, higher prices, and limited opportunities for ordinary Egyptians.
• In 2022, in response to international calls for economic reform, Egypt introduced the State Ownership Policy Document in collaboration with the IMF.

• The policy document outlines Egypt’s strategy to reduce state and military involvement in the economy, aiming to withdraw entirely from certain industries within three years while maintaining or expanding presence in strategic sectors.

• The reforms seek to increase private sector participation by clearly defining the state's economic role, improving governance of state-owned enterprises according to OECD standards, and promoting competitive neutrality.
• By the final quarter of 2024, these reforms resulted in private investment surpassing public investment for the second consecutive quarter, accounting for over half of total investments.

• During this period, private investments increased by 35.4% year-on-year, whereas public investments declined by 25.7%, marking a significant shift from Egypt’s recent history of public investment dominance.
• A report by the Strategic Foresight Group has quantified the opportunity cost of conflict for Egypt since 1991, estimating it to be nearly US $800 billion.
• This figure represents the economic losses attributable to ongoing conflict and instability in the country over this period.
• The report implies that, in the absence of conflict and with peace maintained since 1991, Egypt's economic trajectory would have been significantly different.
• Specifically, if peace had prevailed, the average income of an Egyptian citizen would be over US $3,000 annually, compared to the actual average of US $1,700.
• This suggests that conflict has cost the average Egyptian citizen approximately US $1,300 per year in potential earnings.
